author: costin
msg: Fixed build - forgot JspInterceptor.
BTW, what about enabling ( and fixing the remaining bugs :-) it by default
for 3.3 ?
It's much faster and cleaner, and will allow us to better integrate with
Jasper 1.2. Another risk - but it may be worth it.

author: costin
msg: Removed old server connectors from tomcat.modules.server
We'll keep tomcat.service until the new code is tested, but the new code
is much cleaner and probably have exactly the same functionality as
before.
( probably we should remove old code anyway - and roll back from
cvs in case the new code is worse)

author: costin
msg: Finally, src/share is completely independent of servlet.jar  and we have
a clear layer and module separation.
Tomcat.util is the collection of general-purpose, independent utilities
Tomcat.core represent the web layer ( low-level objects, close to web
server architecture ) and depends _only_ on utils and JDK1.1
Tomcat.modules consists of general modules (independent of servlet.jar,
but acting as adapters for external APIs and tools ), depend on core,
utils and the APIs they plug in ( some may be JDK1.2-specific )
Tomcat.facade is the adapter between core and a certain ServletAPI. Since
core maps ( almost completely ) to all common web servers, and servlet API is
supposed to work with those servers - all servlet API versions can be
supported on this architecture ( including legacy 2.0, and for sure 2.3
and whatever follows - including 3.0 ).
There is only one extension mechanism ( BasicInterceptor ), that mapps to
the extension mechanisms used by common servers, and about 5 core classes that
matter.
Interceptors are the basis of tomcat modularity, and we can tune up individual
components.

author: costin
msg: Ops, forgot a debug statement.

author: costin
msg: - moved the code that handle expiration in a tomcat.util class.
It will be used by ContextManager to unload unused Contexts and servlets,
and may be used for other tasks ( it's a general-purpose tool )
- same refactoring as in core - replaced indirect calls, methods and properties
moved to the object where it belongs, split complex objects in simpler ones,
moved generic code in util.
- the session manager code is now much narrowly focused, and it should be
easier ( in 3.4 + ) to add more sophisticated managers ( database, etc). It's
also much cleanly separated from upper layer.
( some thing may be broken, but most of the refactoring is done.
